M.G.L. c. 218.proposition: Venue is proper in Boston Municipal Court under M.G.L. c. 218, and because the Premises are located in Dorchester, within the court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Javins v. First Nat'l Realty Corp., 428.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat'l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing implied warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies)
Javins v. First Nat'l Realty Corp., 428.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every lease (including implied terms of a tenancy) carries an implied covenant that the tenant shall have quiet enjoyment of the premises, free from substantial interference by the landlord that deprives the tenant of the beneficial use and occupation of the premises.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.raw_text: Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation) (establishing heating requirements and minimum standards)
Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: Massachusetts courts and courts applying Massachusetts law have treated substantial interference with heat, hot water, and similar fundamental services as continuing breaches that may support claims for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and/or implied warranty of habitability.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.raw_text: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (addressing implied warranty of habitability and landlord responsibilities)
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Relevant authorities supporting Plaintiff’s claim include, but are not limited to, the following:
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Hilder v. St. Peter as addressing the implied warranty of habitability and landlord responsibilities. The opinion expressly adopts an implied warranty of habitability in all residential leases, defines the landlord’s duty to deliver and maintain habitable premises, and sets out related remedies and damages. Thus, the case squarely supports the proposition for which it is cited.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. Because we hold that the lease of a residential dwelling creates a contractual relationship between the landlord and tenant, the standard contract remedies of rescission, reformation and damages are available to the tenant when suing for breach of the implied warranty of habitability.”

Leibel v. Stone, 330 Mass. 285 (1953) (M.raw_text: Leibel v. Stone, 330 Mass. 285 (1953) (Mass. Supreme Judicial Court decisions discussing landlord responsibilities — representative Massachusetts precedent addressing tenant rights)
Leibel v. Stone, 330 Mass. 285 (1953) (M.proposition: Relevant authorities supporting Plaintiff’s claim include, but are not limited to, the following:
Leibel v. Stone, 330 Mass. 285 (1953) (M.support_reasoning: The proposition describes this as a landlord‑tenant case on landlord responsibilities and tenant rights. Leibel v. Stone is instead a first‑party insurance dispute about the effect and validity of a fire insurance reference/award and the scope of referees’ authority under the Massachusetts standard fire policy. It does not involve a landlord‑tenant relationship, premises liability, or duties owed by a landlord to a tenant, so it cannot provide relevant authority for that proposition.
Leibel v. Stone, 330 Mass. 285 (1953) (M.relevant_excerpt: “This action of contract on three policies of fire insurance in the Massachusetts standard form seeks to recover for direct loss or damage caused by lightning to the plaintiff’s garage on June 8, 1946. … The statutory provision for reference in the Massachusetts standard policy has been in its present form since St. 1887, c. 214, § 60. Its purpose is to provide a ‘summary method of establishing the amount of the loss.’”

Andrews v. Broderick, 13 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Andrews v. Broderick, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 297 (1982) (Landlord/tenant principles and remedies; consult for Massachusetts analysis of landlord obligations)
Andrews v. Broderick, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Relevant authorities supporting Plaintiff’s claim include, but are not limited to, the following:
Andrews v. Broderick, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition describes Andrews v. Broderick as a landlord/tenant case about landlord obligations and remedies. The provided opinion is actually a Massachusetts child custody/care-and-protection decision involving the Department of Social Services and parental rights, with no discussion of landlord–tenant law, leases, or landlord obligations. Therefore this opinion does not support the stated landlord/tenant proposition and appears to be mis-cited.
Andrews v. Broderick, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The child and her natural parents appeal from a judgment of the Superior Court ordering that permanent custody of the child remain with the Department of Social Services (department) and that the visitation rights previously ordered by the court be terminated. … We think the judge’s findings and rulings meet these guidelines and … are not only not clearly erroneous, but are ‘amply justified by the totality of the evidence.’”

Patrin v. Smith, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (.raw_text: Patrin v. Smith, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (1985) (Mass. Appeals Court discussion of tenant remedies where landlord breached duties — illustrative)
Patrin v. Smith, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (.proposition: Relevant authorities supporting Plaintiff’s claim include, but are not limited to, the following:
Patrin v. Smith, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (.support_reasoning: The cited opinion is a juvenile criminal case about jury instructions on witness credibility (particularly police officers and child witnesses) and the permissible scope of cross-examination. It does not concern landlord–tenant law, tenant remedies, or landlord breaches of duty in any way. Therefore it cannot support a proposition about tenant remedies for landlord breaches and appears to be a miscitation for that purpose.
Patrin v. Smith, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (.relevant_excerpt: "The main question on this appeal is whether the trial judge committed error when he declined to elaborate on his general instructions on the credibility of witnesses to deal more particularly with the credibility of police officers (the complainant, Boston police Officer Thomas Richardson, being the one in question) and child witnesses (Richard Flores, called by the prosecution). We hold that the judge acted within his reasonable discretion, and did not err."
